text.p: VIENNA July 8 (Reuter) The main stories in the Austrian press this Tuesday are:
DER STANDARD
- Train from Vienna to Czech Republic derailed, over 60 injured but none seriously.
- Chancellor Viktor Klima is not ruling anything out ahead of NATO summit in Madrid. Debate over entry intensifies.

- Opposition parties are to bring a vote of no confidence against two ministers in the last week before parliament's summer recess. Foreign Minister Wolfgang Schuessel will be grilled in question time on the theme of 'representation of the government abroad'. The other motion will be brought against Defence Minister Werner Fasslabend.
- The building industry demands the introduction of a kilometer toll on motorways. It is vehemently opposed to a decision by the Chamber of Economy to hinder a road pricing plan.
- Bawag bank wants to go into business with Bausparkasse Wuestenrot, which has gone public and is looking for strategic partners.
- The government plans to find more money for the budget by digging some 5.5 billion schillings out of unemployment insurance to pay for pensions.

- President of Bank Austria's supervisory board Siegfried Sellitsch criticises the privatisation of the Bank of Austria. He says the time limit weighs down the share price and leads to the destruction of national wealth.
- The Residenz-Immobilien real estate group could reduce its deficit in its pre-tax profit to 7.9 million schillings from 8.2 million.
DIE PRESSE
- A new survey suggests that 37% of Austrians are optimistic about their country's economic climate, up from 29% in the previous year.
- Concessions for executives. The government and civil servants' union has reached an agreement on minor cuts for executives going into early retirement.
- New intrigues in PSK poker. Wuestenrot receives new shareholders. In the fight to get stake in the Postsparkasse, Wuestenrot hedges itself many times.
KURIER
- Klima says he's not in a hurry over NATO ahead of the Madrid summit.
- A suicide by a nurse who accidently caused the death of an elderly patient has sparked calls for more intensive training and stress management for staff.
- Domestic investment funds going like hot cakes. Investment fund capital grew in the first half of the year to 82.5 billion Austrian schillings.
- Euro: EU finance ministers approve Italy's saving package. Austrian Finance Minister Rudolf Edlinger says France and Italy will be ready to join EMU in 1999.
- Privatisation: Vienna stockmarket is threatened with a billion schilling collapse. Sale of Bank Austria shares and First/Giro launch on to the stockmarket could over burden the money market.
DIE NEUE KRONE ZEITUNG
Klima: "Coalition remains intact".
